data.title: Winter storm timeline: When will the heaviest lake effect snow hit and where?
authors: Democrat and Chronicle, Democrat and Chronicle
data.meta_description: What to know about the winter storm threatening our area and its timing.

Winter storms hit across the U.S.

Winter weather is hitting cities across the country. Parts of northern Utah are under avalanche warnings this week following a series of severe winter storms.

Fox - 26 Houston

Heavy lake effect snow is expected over the next few days, with total snow accumulations of 1 to 3 feet in the most persistent lake bands. A lake effect snow warning is in effect for parts of western New York, including parts of the Rochester region.

What to know about the storm and its timing, according to the National Weather Service in Buffalo:

Affected Areas:

Erie, Genesee, and Wyoming counties.

Lake effect storm warning in effect:

From 1 p.m. Tuesday through 7 p.m. Thursday.

Impacts from the storm:

Travel could be very difficult to impossible.

Hazardous conditions may affect morning or evening commutes.

Cold wind chills pose a risk of hypothermia if precautions are not taken.

Precautionary/Preparedness Actions:

Heavy snowfall in narrow bands requires travelers to be prepared for rapidly changing road conditions and reduced visibilities.

Timeline of winter storm in western New York

Tuesday Afternoon:

The lake effect snow band is centered on Ski Country during the afternoon.

Tuesday Night:

The lake effect snow band is expected to slowly shift north through southern Erie and Wyoming counties.

It will reach the Buffalo Metro area by early Wednesday morning.

Wednesday Morning to Wednesday Night:

The lake effect snow band will remain over the Buffalo Metro area through the first half of Wednesday night.

Winds gusting as high as 40 mph are forecasted, resulting in areas of blowing and drifting snow.

Travel conditions may become difficult, mainly Wednesday afternoon and evening.

It's possible that parts of the Monroe County could see lake effect snow from the band on Wednesday and bring snow accumulation, but it depends on how Tuesday's weather progresses, according to the Weather Service.

Wednesday Night to Thursday Morning:

The lake effect snow band is projected to shift back south of Buffalo.

Travel difficulties may persist, impacting morning and evening commutes.

Cold wind chills as low as 20 below zero are expected Wednesday night, posing a risk of hypothermia without precautions.

Thursday Afternoon:

The lake effect snow band will shift back north across the Buffalo Metro area.

Weakening of the snow band is anticipated.
